Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
On 3/03/22, two youth were fighting, and security staff came to Yes
intervene. Youth A was restrained during the process. Another
staff member was reported to observe the fighting and failed to
physically intervene to stop the fighting.
III. METHODOLOGY
03/10/2022 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0207023
03/10/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Discussed incident with the facility Director. Reviewed restraint IR.
03/10/2022 Contact - Document Sent
Complaint information forwarded to DCWL Intake and DHHS

03/10/2022 Contact - Document Received

03/14/2022 Contact - Face to Face

ALLEGATION:
On 3/03/22, two youth were fighting, and security staff came to intervene. Youth A
was restrained during the process. Another staff member was reported to observe
the fighting and failed to physically intervene to stop the fighting.
2

INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 03/10/22 and investigated jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. I sent the information for this complaint to DCWL Intake and Centralized
Intake after concerns arose during a restraint report review from this situation with
the Director.
As part of this investigation, I reviewed video of this incident. Video review is
summarized as follows: The video started at 11:59:53. Staff 1 was observed in the
control room and Youths A, B, C, and D were observed in the day room area of the
pod. There was no other staff in the day room with the four youth, who were at a
table. About 12:01:06, Youth A gets up, followed by Youth B and the two begin
throwing punches, fighting, and wrestling one another to the floor. About 12:01:29,
Staff 1 exited the control room and walked toward the youth. Staff 1 was observed
on his radio (reportedly calling for assistance) about 12:01:38. Staff 1 then opened
bedroom doors. About 12:01:49 additional staff entered the pod and Security Officer
(SO) 2 attempted to intervene and separate the two fighting youth. The boys got up
and SO2 put Youth A in a restraint at about 12:02:07. Staff 1 did not assist in
separating the youth or physically intervening with either youth. Other security and
supervisors who entered the pod intervened with both youths. While being restrained
by SO2, Youth A attempted to go after another peer and that peer was escorted
away by Supervisor 2. Youth A was the escorted to his room by SO2 and SO1 at
about 12:02:43. Youth B tried to get back at Youth A and was held back by
Supervisor 1. Youth B then walked away, and it appeared staff were giving him
space to calm down. The video ended about 12:12:11.
I interviewed the Director on 03/14/22, jointly with the DHHS Specialist. The Director
reviewed the video with us and acknowledged that Staff 1 was in the control room
too long and should have intervened in separating the fighting youth. The Director
said that Staff 1 did not have any disciplinary action in his employee file and there
were no active safety plans involving Staff 1. The Director said that she met with
Staff 1 the prior Friday and reviewed supervision expectations.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility, on 03/14/22, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker and placement therapist were present at the interview
for support but did not actively participate. Youth A provided a consistent report of
the incident as compared to what was reviewed on video. Youth A noted Staff 1 was
in the control room while the other 4 youth were on the pod. Youth A said that Youth
B got mad and hit Youth A, so Youth A hit Youth B back. They continued fighting
and repeatedly hitting one another. Youth A said Staff 1 came out of the control
room and opened bedroom doors but did not physically intervene “because he’s an
old man”. Youth A did say that Staff 1 “hurried up” and called security for assistance.
Youth A said that security came in, as well as more staff to separate the youth and
Youth A was escorted to his bedroom. Youth A said he was not injured in the
incident.
Youths B, C, and D were interviewed at the facility on 03/14/22, jointly with the
3

DHHS Specialist. Youths B and D reported a fairly consistent account of the
incident. Youth B additionally reported that he thought Staff 1 was in the control
room for 30-40 minutes and didn’t come out for about two minutes after the fight
began. Youth B said that he and Youth A got into another fight later that evening.
Youth C didn’t remember a lot about the incident including details of the fight or Staff
1’s whereabouts or actions during the fight. Youth C reported that there is always at
least one staff with the youth. Youth D reported that Staff 1 had been in the control
room a “couple minutes” before the fight started.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility, on 03/23/22, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 1 reported that he usually works midnight shift but is often mandated to stay
over for day shift, as he was this day. Staff 1 reported working anywhere from 80-
120 hours per two-week pay period for several years and that administration does
not do anything about it. Regarding this incident, Staff 1 said that Youths A and B
had built up to the fight by earlier conflicts that day. Staff 1 said he went in the
control room and was talking to a teacher about issues like the youth’s computer
usage, bringing personal items on the pod, managing rising youth tension and how
to manage the kids to avoid issues. Staff 1 said he was also doing paperwork while
in the control room. Staff 1 said this was done in the control room to have a private
conversation with the teacher and to keep the papers safe. Staff 1 said that he has
since reevaluated the way he operates and is bringing the paperwork onto the pod.
Staff 1 said that he was also told to call for assistance/support, even with the “small
things.” Staff 1 said that leaving the pod unmanned at any time is not the
expectation. Staff 1 said that he was in the control room for three to four minutes
total. When asked why he did not physically intervene in the fighting, Staff 1 said that
he would have only been able to secure one youth, which would have left that youth
vulnerable for the other youth to assault. Staff 1 said that he opened bedroom doors
to get the other two youth out of the way and called for assistance. This reportedly
happened about the same time that the security and supervisors came on the pod.
Staff 1 reported to be current on his restraint training and indicated he had no
disciplinary action in his 10 years of employment.
Supervisors 1, 2, and 3 were interviewed at the facility, on 03/23/22, jointly with the
DHHS Specialist. Both Supervisors 1 and 2 reported a consistent account of the
incident as compared to the video. Supervisor 3 said that most of the incident was
over when he arrived. Supervisor 1 held Youth B back when Youth B tried to get at
Youth A. Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 said that there is not as much overtime as
there used to be. Supervisor 1 noted that Staff 1 asks for overtime. All three
Supervisors said that staff have been advised to stay on the floor and radio the
supervisors/security for assistance when they need something. They said staff were
directed not to be in the control room doing paperwork or leaving the pod without a
staff in proximity to the youth. When the youth are in their rooms on reflection time,
the staff can complete their paperwork. Both Supervisors reviewed the security
protocol for staff and teachers entering the building. Teachers are permitted to bring
personal items to their offices but not on the pod.
4

In a follow-up meeting with the Director and DHHS Specialist, on 03/23/22, the
Director reported that Staff 1 was in the control room for about 12 minutes, noting
that he entered the control room at about 11:49:48. The Director discussed the
mandated overtime and noted Staff 1 is kept over about three times per week. The
Director reviewed security protocol for staff and teachers entering the building and
noted that she is not aware of any teachers or staff bringing personal items on the
pods. It was noted that teachers can bring their belongings to their lounge but only
items needed for school are brought to the classrooms or pods. The Director
confirmed that she directed supervisors to provide additional assistance to staff so
that no pod is left without a staff for even a brief time such as a staff going in the
control room.
Security Officers (SO) 1 and 2 were interviewed at the facility, on 03/23/22, jointly
with the DHHS Specialist. Both SOs reported consistent accounts of the incident as
reviewed on video. Both SOs said that staff and teachers are not allowed to bring
personal items on the pod and noted security wands staff upon entry.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 MiSACWIS Incident Report for this incident. The report was consistent with
the incident but did not address Staff 1’s whereabouts prior to and during the
fight.
 Unusual Incident Report Summary, authored by the Facility Manager, dated
03/03/22. The report was consistent with the incident but did not address Staff
1’s whereabouts.
 Restraint training records for Staff 1. Staff 1 was current on restraint training.
 Medical documentation from post-incident exam of Youth A and Youth B.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
5

ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule, evidenced by Staff 1 being
observed, on video review, in the control room for over 11
minutes without other staff on the pod with the four youth. When
the two youth began fighting, Staff 1 left the control room,
entered the day room, and called on the radio for assistance.
Staff 1 then unlocked bedroom doors for the other youth to get
away from the incident. Youth A and Youth B continued fighting
during this time. Staff 1 did not make any attempts to physically
separate them or stop the fighting. The fight was attended to by
the supervisors and security who arrived at the area shortly after
Staff 1 called for assistance. The lack of proximal supervision by
Staff 1, especially when Staff 1 reported the youth were having
conflict earlier in the day, and his lack of action to physically
separate the youth did not provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of the residents.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan addressing the noted violation.
